China Construction Bank Fraud Prevention Department Notification  
Date: October 12, 2023 | Reference No.: CCB-FP-20231012-089  

Recipient: Ms. Li Wenjing (Account Holder: 6214 8123 5678 4321)  

Subject: Urgent Alert Regarding Suspicious Transfer Activity  

Dear Ms. Li,  

Our system has flagged a recent transaction request linked to your account (CCB 4321) for review. Below are critical details requiring your immediate attention:  

1. Transaction Details

   - Platform Reference: "Fanda APP" (unverified third-party application).  

2. Identified Red Flags  
   - Unsolicited Contact: Legitimate financial institutions (e.g., Douyin) do not initiate investment offers via unsolicited messages or direct transfers to personal/unknown corporate accounts.  
   - High-Return Promises: Claims of "immediate returns" or unusually high yields are common hallmarks of investment fraud.  
   - Account Mismatch: Transfers to unrelated third-party corporate accounts (e.g., Shanghai Yitong Digital Commerce Co., Ltd.) for "investment purposes" violate standard protocols.

China Construction Bank  
Fraud Prevention Department  
Hotline: 95533 | Email: fraudalert@ccb.com  
Protecting Your Assets Is Our Priority

one-round response:
This kind of message warrants your attention—but with caution. It appears to be alerting you to potentially suspicious activity, so it’s important not to ignore it. At the same time, you must ensure that the notification itself is authentic. Here are the steps you should take:

1. Verify the Message’s Authenticity  
 • Do not use any phone numbers, links, or email addresses provided in the text message.  
 • Instead, contact your bank directly using trusted, official contact information (for example, the customer service or fraud hotline number found on your bank statement, official website, or the back of your debit/credit card).  
 • Ask if they have sent you any notification regarding suspicious transactions in your account.

2. Do Not Provide Any Sensitive Information  
 • If you receive a call or additional message asking for personal details such as passwords, verification codes, or account numbers, do not provide them until you have confirmed the legitimacy of the request through an independently obtained official channel.

3. Review Your Account Activity  
 • Log into your banking app or online banking (using your saved bookmarks or official app, not links from the message) and review recent transactions.  
 • If you notice any unauthorized activity, report it immediately.

4. Report Suspicious Activity  
 • If you determine the message is a scam or if it appears the fraudulent attempt is targeting you, report it to your bank’s fraud prevention team using the contact methods given on your official bank communications or website.  
 • You can also report it to local authorities or your country’s cybercrime unit, following the official procedure.

5. Stay Informed and Educated  
 • Keep yourself updated on common scam tactics such as unsolicited high-return investment offers or requests for immediate action.  
 • Your bank may have resources or guidelines on how to recognize and deal with such fraud notifications.

In summary, you should take the matter seriously—verify it independently before taking any action, and avoid using the contact information provided in the message until you confirm its authenticity. This way, you protect both your assets and personal information while ensuring you’re following a proper procedure for any potential fraud alert.

one-round response:
This message raises several red flags that suggest you should treat it with caution:

1. Unsolicited communication and generic greeting: The message doesn’t address you by name but uses “Dear Valued Client,” which is common in phishing attempts.

2. Sensitive information already provided: It references specific personal data (your date of birth, maternal family name, etc.) that was supposedly exchanged during a recent interaction. If you weren’t involved in such an update, this is concerning.

3. Alternative contact channels: The message offers multiple phone numbers and an email. However, these details may not be consistent with those on the official website or your previous communications with your institution.

4. Emphasis on urgency and immediate action: The direction to “confirm or update” your security preferences can be a tactic to trick you into responding quickly without verifying the legitimacy of the communication.

5. Mention of “intentional indicators of potential fraud”: The note at the end even highlights red flags intended for training, hinting this could be a mock exercise or a simulated phishing attempt.

Based on these concerns, here’s how you should handle the situation:

• Do Not Respond or Click Any Links: Avoid replying or following any prompts within the message until you’ve verified its authenticity.

• Validate Directly via Official Channels: 
  – Independently locate the official contact information (e.g., the customer service phone number and website) from your institution’s official communications, documents, or their verified website.
  – Call or visit the institution in person to ask if they have sent any such notification and confirm if any action is required on your account.

• Do Not Share Sensitive Information: If you haven’t already confirmed the activity through an established official procedure, do not provide any personal details or security information through the provided channels.

• Report the Message: Notify your institution’s fraud or security team by forwarding the message (or its details) so they can confirm whether it is legitimate or if it’s part of a phishing scheme.

In summary, while you may recognize aspects of the described activity, it’s best to verify independently using trusted contact methods. This approach will help ensure your account’s security and protect against potential scams.

one-round response:
This message contains several red flags that are commonly associated with scams or phishing attempts. Here are some points to consider and steps you should take:

1. Unusual Requirements: Reputable financial institutions generally do not ask you to transfer money or pay a deposit to secure a credit card application. A request for a security deposit of 50,000 RMB in order to "verify your financial capacity" is highly unconventional.

2. Pressure Tactics: Scams often use urgency or an expedited process (for example, claiming the card will be activated within 5–7 business days) to prompt hasty actions. Legitimate processes typically do not require you to act so immediately, especially by transferring funds before the credit is even granted.

3. Unverified Contact Methods: The text directs you to contact them via WeChat or email and provides phone numbers and addresses that may be fabricated. If you did not initiate this inquiry or show any signs of being engaged with this company previously, it’s best to be cautious.

4. Cross-Checking Authenticity:  
   • Search for the company online, but be aware that scammers can mimic names and websites that look official.  
   • Instead of using the provided contact information, independently look up official numbers or visit the official website of the bank or a known credit card provider to verify if such a program exists.  
   • Contact ICBC or your own bank directly to ask if they have any record of this offer or if the bank account details match any known channels.

5. Do Not Provide Sensitive Information: Until you are absolutely sure about the legitimacy of the message, do not forward any sensitive information, deposit funds, or send screenshots of your transaction.

6. Report if Necessary:  
   • If you suspect that it may be a scam, consider reporting the message to local authorities or consumer protection agencies.  
   • You might also report it to your bank or financial institution so that they can warn other customers if it turns out to be fraudulent.

In summary, you should be very cautious with any unsolicited financial offers that require an upfront deposit or immediate action. The appropriate course of action is to avoid transferring any money or providing personal information until you have independently verified the authenticity of the offer through trusted and official channels.

one-round response:
This message contains several red flags that suggest it could be part of a scam or phishing attempt. Here’s what to consider and how to handle it:

1. Suspicious Content and Claims
 • The message promises unusually high, guaranteed returns (e.g., 18–24% per annum) with “very low risk” — a claim that’s highly uncommon in legitimate investments.
 • It uses vague language like “multiple successful cases” without verifiable details.
 • There’s an urgency to click on external links, which can be a method for phishing or delivering malware.

2. Questionable Contact Details
 • The external website (www.zh-investments-ad.cn) and the information provided (e.g., the new domain registration) are suspicious.
 • The sender’s contact details (phone number and email) may appear professional, but scammers often create messages that mimic credible sources.

3. Recommended Course of Action
 • Do not click on the provided links or call the numbers listed until you’ve independently verified this information.
 • Instead, directly visit official websites (for example, the official China Securities Regulatory Commission website at www.csrc.gov.cn) or use contact details you have independently verified.
 • If you’re interested in an investment or concerned about a potential scam, contact your bank or a trusted financial advisor.
 • Report the message to relevant authorities. In this case, forwarding the message to the Anti-Fraud Center (report@antifraud110.cn) might be advisable.
 • Block the sender if you determine the message to be a scam.

4. Overall Considerations
 • Legitimate financial institutions and investment opportunities are rarely promoted through unsolicited text messages.
 • Always approach high-return offers with a healthy dose of skepticism, particularly when the risk details are vague or when urgent action is pushed.

In summary, you should pay attention to this message only enough to verify its legitimacy through trusted channels. Avoid engaging with the message directly, and report it if necessary. Your caution here protects you from potential fraud.

1. Red Flags to Note:
   • Urgency and Threats: It pressures you to act within 24 hours to avoid “penalties” and “legal action.”
   • Unusual Requests: It instructs you to withdraw funds and transfer them to a specific account, which is uncommon for legitimate financial service notifications.
   • Contact Information: Although it provides telephone numbers and email addresses, these may be spoofed. Always verify contact details independently.
   • Regulatory Claims: The reference to regulatory breaches and immediate deactivation of a service tends to be used as a scare tactic.

2. Recommended Actions:
   • Do Not Act on the Instructions: Do not call any provided phone numbers, do not transfer any money, and avoid clicking on any links.
   • Verify Through Official Channels: Contact your bank or the legitimate financial institution using official contact details from their website or your account statements. Ask if there’s any issue with your account.
   • Report the Message: Forward the message to your bank’s fraud department or report it to your local consumer protection agency. Also, mark it as “spam” or “phishing” in your messaging app.
   • Do Not Provide Personal or Financial Information: Avoid sharing any sensitive information like verification codes, passwords, or account details.

3. Summary:
Based on the content and tactics used in the message, it is best to treat it as suspicious. Always verify any financial communications by reaching out directly to your bank or service provider using verified contact information. When in doubt, it’s safer to err on the side of caution.

If you remain uncertain, consider seeking additional advice from your bank’s security team or a trusted financial advisor. This proactive approach will help ensure your personal and financial information remains secure.

one-round response:
This message is highly suspicious and appears to be a scam. Here’s why you should be cautious and what you should do:

1. Scare Tactics and Urgency – The message creates a false sense of urgency by setting strict deadlines and threatening account suspension. Legitimate institutions rarely, if ever, impose such immediate deadlines or pressure you into transferring funds.

2. Request for Transfers to Personal Accounts – Real financial institutions and reputable platforms use designated corporate accounts under strict regulations. Requests to transfer money to named individuals (such as Zhang San, Li Si, Wang Wu) are a common tactic employed by fraudsters.

3. Contact Information Verification – The provided phone numbers and email addresses are likely not connected to any official services. Always check an institution’s official website or your previous trusted communications for legitimate contact details.

4. Inconsistent Messaging – Although the notice includes a “Security Advisory” warning about fraudulent practices, this dual-message approach is a well-known strategy of scammers to confuse the recipient and create a sense of authenticity.

Steps to Handle the Situation:

• Do Not Transfer Any Money – Do not follow any instructions or deadlines mentioned in the message.

• Verify Independently – Contact your financial institution or the official support channels of the investment platform (using contact details from their verified website or past official communications) to confirm if there is any issue with your account.

• Do Not Reply – Avoid replying to the message or clicking on any links it might contain (if applicable).

• Report the Message – Forward the message to your bank and, if possible, report it to local consumer protection agencies or your national cybercrime unit. Many banks also have dedicated fraud or scam reporting channels.

• Delete It – Once you have reported the incident and verified with the appropriate authorities, delete the message to avoid any accidental interaction later.

In summary, pay close attention to the red flags and treat this message as a fraudulent attempt. Verifying through official channels instead of reacting to urgent demands will help protect your assets. Stay alert and safe.

4. Urgency and Pressure: Scam messages often use urgent language and pressure you to take immediate action, hoping that you won’t take the time to verify details properly.

• Verify Through Official Channels: Contact Zhonghang Securities directly using contact numbers or email addresses listed on their official website. Do not use the contact information provided in the text message until you have confirmed its legitimacy independently.

• Report the Message: Consider reporting the message to your bank or local consumer protection agency if you are in doubt. They might be aware of similar scams and can provide additional guidance.

• Be Cautious with Unsolicited Offers: If you weren’t expecting a refund or have not previously been involved in any such transaction with the institution, the message is even more likely to be fraudulent.

In summary, treat the message with caution. It’s best to verify its authenticity using only the official contact channels of Zhonghang Securities. If it turns out to be a scam, having taken these precautions will help protect your personal and financial information.

• Report the Message:

1. Red Flags in the Message:

 • Urgency and Pressure: The tight deadline of 48 hours and the claim that only three slots remain are clear pressure tactics designed to prompt a quick, unconsidered decision.
 • Generic or Unverified Sender Details: Although the message appears to be from a “Senior Partnership Manager” and includes contact information, the domain (@eliterecruitnet.com) and lack of a verifiable business address are concerning. Also, the request for immediate action without prior contact is typical of phishing attempts.
 • Promised ROI Claims: Guaranteeing a 300% ROI is highly unusual and unrealistic in the recruiting and talent acquisition market. Legitimate platforms do not guarantee returns in such specific terms.
 • Suspicious Attachments: Files like “EliteRecruit_CaseStudies.pdf” and “VIP_Terms_of_Service.pdf” might contain malware or phishing content, especially if they come from an unverified source.

2. Fraud Awareness Test Questions Reflected:
 • All options in Question 1 (unsolicited payment request, generic email, tight deadline) are red flags.
 • In Question 2, the guaranteed ROI promise is a red flag because such returns are atypical and are used as a sales tactic.
 • For Question 3, the urge to act immediately combined with attachment details makes them suspicious. Consistently, the overall email format and its contents suggest caution.

3. What to Do:
 • Do Not Respond or Send Money: Do not reply to the email or make any wire transfers. Avoid clicking or downloading any attachments.
 • Verify the Offer: If you’re even slightly interested, independently verify the legitimacy of the offer. This means reaching out via official contact information you find on the company’s verified website or known business directories—not by replying to the email provided.
 • Report the Email: Consider reporting the suspicious email to your company’s IT or cybersecurity team so they can take appropriate action. You might also report it to relevant fraud prevention authorities if needed.
 • Educate Colleagues: Share the details of this phishing attempt with others in your organization if applicable, so that everyone remains alert to similar scams.

In conclusion, yes—you should pay attention to the message, but only as a cautionary example of what a phishing or fraudulent attempt can look like. Do not take any actions (such as replying, clicking attachments, or transferring funds) until you have independently verified the authenticity of the sender and the offer. Stay safe by following secure verification procedures and consulting with your IT/security team.

one-round response:

2. Requesting Money to a Third-Party Account: The message instructs you to transfer funds to an account supposedly belonging to someone else (Yutong’s father), rather than directly addressing the problem through official channels. This is another common tactic used in scams.

3. Verification of the Sender: The sender’s identity (Li Wei) and the context provided (an altercation at a school) should be independently verified. 4. Inconsistencies and Unusual Requests: A genuine urgent assistance request related to an incident at school would typically be handled through established procedures by the school, rather than through a text message asking you to transfer such a large sum of money.

Appropriate Actions to Take:

– Do not transfer any money or follow any instructions in the message until you have independently verified its authenticity.
  
– Contact Li Wei (or the person you believe the message is from) by using a trusted and known contact method (phone call, official email, etc.) to confirm if they actually sent this request.
  
– If the situation is supposedly related to an incident involving a school, contact the school administration directly using publicly available contact details to see if there’s any record of such an incident or any official communication regarding it.
  
– Consider reporting the suspicious message to your local authorities or to your bank’s fraud department, so that it can be investigated.

In summary, do not respond or send any money before confirming that the request is legitimate. Taking these steps should help prevent you from falling victim to a scam.
